top_categories.workout_context: 56ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Wollombi Gravel Fest's Gravel roads, Valley terrain forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 62 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Wollombi Gravel Fest's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before December.
At Wollombi Gravel Fest, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Wollombi Gravel Fest. Train it until it feels boring.
62 miles on valley gravel roads burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
When someone attacks on valley gravel roads, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
Varied gradients on valley gravel roads demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Wollombi Gravel Fest, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on valley gravel roads. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Low-cadence force work for 3,500ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Wollombi Gravel Fest’s 62 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Wollombi Gravel Fest requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on valley gravel roads to build confidence. Expect: gravel roads, valley terrain, rolling hills.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 62 miles of valley gravel roads in Wollombi Valley, New South Wales.
